Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Development of an Adaptive Optic Scanning Laser Microscope for Deep Tissue Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the field of astronomy, adaptive optics are used to correct for the image aberrations that occur as starlight passes through the Earth's atmosphere: Dynamic changes in the refractive index refract the light, causing stars to "twinkle." The adaptive optics that are used in large terrestrial telescopes consist of a wavefront sensor to measure the aberrations of a "guide star," a natural or artificial point source reference beacon in the field of view of the object of interest, and a deformable mirror that can dynamically change its shape correct the image to restore diffraction limited imaging.
The adaptive optics used in astronomy to obtain clearer images of celestial bodies in outer space will be re-applied in the field of biological imaging to correct image aberrations from changes in the refractive index within a cell. A fluorescent bead will be used as the reference beacon and implanted near the object of interest, such as the nucleus of a cell. Expected outcome is the correction of highly aberrated images, thereby obtaining the resolution limit set by diffraction of the imaging system. Once developed, the microscope will be available in a new research center, funded by the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine (www.cirm.ca.gov).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The title of the project is “IDBR: Development of an Adaptive Optical Scanning Laser Microscope for Deep Tissue Imaging.” The results of this work have been published in three refereed journal articles[i],[ii],[iii] and two conference proceeding publications.[iv],[v] The research activities in this proposal included opportunities for an undergraduate (Ziah Dean) and graduate students (Janelle Yong, Bautista Fernandez and Oscar Azucena) to participate in a multidisciplinary research team consisting of optical physicists (Don Gavel and Scot Olivier), electrical engineers (Joel Kubby and Diana Chen), and biologists (Yi Zuo, Min Fu and Denise Garcia).  Ziah Dean, Janelle Yong, Bautista Fernandez and Oscar Azucena are all associated with underrepresented groups, thus broadening the participation of underrepresented groups. Each of these students disseminated their results at professional meetings held by the Society of Optical Engineers (SPIE) and at the Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) research review meetings. Ziah Dean graduated from UC Santa Cruz with a B.S. in Biomedical Engineering, Janelle Yong received her M.S. in Electrical Engineering and is continuing on in a Ph.D. program, and Bautista Fernandez and Oscar Azucena have received their Ph.D.’s in Electrical Engineering. The results of this research were also included in presentations given to students in the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (COSMOS), a summer residential program for high school scholars with demonstrated interest and achievement in math and science.

 

The AO confocal microscope that was developed in this program is now available at the W.M. Keck Center for Adaptive Optical Microscopy (cfaom@soe.ucsc.edu). It has been used to image samples from the Sullivan (drosophila embryo) and Zuo (mouse brain tissue) labs in Molecular and Cellular Development Biology at UC Santa Cruz, mouse lung tissue samples from the Krummel lab in Pathology & Laboratory Medicine at UC San Francisco, mouse kidney tissue samples from the Dunn lab, Indiana University School of Medicine, and mouse bone tissue from Ching-Cheng Chen, City of Hope National Medical Center. The most relevant result for the current proposal are the demonstration of adaptive optical correction using direct wavefront sensing, the use of fluorescent protein guide-stars for making wavefront measurements and diffraction limited live imaging. As shown in Figure XX, GFP-polo labeled centrosomes in a Drosophila embryo can be seen with AO correction, but not without it.
